so 20 years ago when i was working at another company on the data warehouse product there's a different endpoint
between memory and cpu and io but the thing of it is is that memory
and cpu are on the semiconductor curve they follow moore's law the performance and capacity double
every two years hard disk drives follow a different kind of physics you know first you need to
move the disk head to the right track then you need to wait for the disk to spin around to the right sector
and so performance is getting better there too but it's doubling every two years i mean sorry 10 years and so
what that means is is that over the first 10 years in data warehousing there's a factor of 16 in
difference between where the original design point was over the next 10 years in data warehousing
that factor's grown to 256. basically data warehousing is an i o
problem amazon redshift dramatically reduces i o
so there's a bunch of stuff i'll go and touch on here and it's a bunch of stuff that i'm sure a lot of you already know about but just
to get everybody in the room up to the same sort of speed most databases are
what we call row major format that means that the columns of an individual row are placed next to each other and if you
think about it you know basically that kind of makes sense you'd insert one row
you're probably doing one io you read one row you're probably doing one i o assuming
it's not even cat it's not cached now you're not going to get any caching in the data warehouse because you're streaming a lot of data
off of disk and let's think about the fact of the case
where you have 100 columns in your table
and you're reading just 10. so then 90 of the data you're reading is useless to
you so instead for a little while now people are working on column major databases
where each block contains the data for just one column and that way i just read the columns
that i care about for my query and as long as there's a pretty significant ratio between the columns
that i'm reading versus the columns that exist for a row i get all of that benefit you know maybe you can think of that as maybe around
10x the second thing that becomes interesting is is that you can do a lot
better data compression on the column by column basis so for example
strings compress kind of differently from dates and numbers low cardinality data like states
compressed differently than high cardinality data like books somebody might be buying data
that's sorted is uh has some advantages about the kind of compression you
might do versus data that's not sorted so you know that's all about sort of reducing ios
secondly we apply a bunch of advanced techniques around just not doing ios at all where possible so for example
we'll keep metadata around for each block to give us a sense of what might be inside it and so
if we know that what the data that we're looking for couldn't possibly be inside this block we're just going to avoid reading it entirely
so third you know after we also try to just make the i o that we do more efficient so for example
redshift uses direct attached storage directly on each compute node so that we don't have the overhead of bringing that data in
across the network we have much higher throughput and bandwidth for the data and we have
you know we also just try to make sure that we're using large block sizes we place the blocks uh sequential fairly sequentially on
disks that were possible a lot of different techniques this is just really a sample side but basically we spend a lot of our time thinking
about io secondly the other big sort of thing
that i think is transformative in the data warehousing industry is about the move towards scale out
architectures and when i first started working in databases the base problem was one of how to take
advan how to basically parcel out these scarce expensive resources that
were available in let's say you know a vax cluster or something like that
the problem shifted hardware is the next thing to free nowadays the real problem nowadays is how to take
advantage of the abundance of resources that you have so let's take an example of what we do in redshift so
if you have a query we're basically going to come in through a jdbc odbc interface to a leader node it's responsible for doing
the parsing and the query optimization and it'll parcel out tasks to a bunch of compute nodes which
each have locally attached disks they process their pieces they do a lot of swizzling in between them they send results back to the leader
node and so that scales out on commodity hardware with the number of compute nodes you have rather than
having to do a forklift upgrade of a big you know single node box
so to this point really most of what i've been
talking about is common with a lot of different columnar

dump in parallel from one and load in parallel from the other and the cool thing about that is while

you decide that you don't want to use redshift anymore turn off your key appliance you know all the data's garbage suddenly
for us right back up to s3 i mean backups are actually a pretty interesting problem at
scale so our but backups to s3 are continuous incremental and automatic so what we do whenever we
go and add data to the system and create a new data block is that we're going to go and
synchronously store it on some other node and some other disk within the cluster
and we're also going to asynchronously store it up into s3 and
that means that two things one thing it means is that if you lose a disk we actually get
pretty decent performance and being able to not actually have to rebuild that disk
before you know and we don't have any failures with respect to your queries we're just going to end up doing an iot
both the network i o as well as the real i o on another disc somewhere else in the cluster and pull it back in over the wire let's
say you have a larger outage where both the primary and the secondary uh field inside the cluster go down
in that case we're going to still keep things um transparent from a query perspective but
we're going to pull in that uh data block from s3 and s3's got eleven nines durability i mean we don't
really worry a lot about uh well i mean they do i don't about uh about losing
data there um if you have a node failure we'll provision a new node
bring the cluster back up and at that point it's basically a node with 24 disks that are failed and it's running the same way
actually a lot of the failures that go on are more transitory rather than uh um
you know sort of like a disc failure where like for example you momentarily lose power or you
momentarily have a network blip in those cases we try to make sure that we actually get placed back onto the
same node with the disk with the data on top of it rather than having to provision a new node which you
know is going to have to do this sort of restore and so you know let's say okay there's a bigger failure some
sort of hurricane or flood or what have you and you need to end up in a different region or a different a z
so you know a lot of the tricks that i've talked about haven't worked so there we have a new feature called streaming
restore where we'll make the system come up as soon as we get pull the metadata down
and then we're it's available for queries and you know those queries are going to
we're populating the disks in parallel in the background but we're also letting you run your
queries and the data blocks are going to fault in from s3 if we haven't yet got them local and the
reason we're doing that is is that if you take us a system like aws data warehouse
well it's got more than three years of data in it but most of our queries are for the last
day or the last week and so that means that once you get less
than one percent of the data back in most of the queries are running just great again
